title: Typeface for Magazine Subheads
content:
Hi all,  
As always, I believe that the knowledge of the collective far outweighs that of the individual. So, once again, I turn to typophile for suggestions.

I'm looking for a great, black or bold weighted, legible typeface to use for subheads in a brand new, high end magazine I'm currently designing. I would like it to have minor traits of art deco without compromising its legibility. I have something in mind for the layout that requires the chosen typeface to be on the bold side.

Any suggestions are appreciated and thanks in advance!
author: Alfonso

comments.content:
Depending upon how "deco" you want to go here is a small selection:  
 [Anisette](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020145725/http:/www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/Anisette) and [Anisette Petite](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020145725/http:/www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/AnisettePetite) from Porchez Typofonderie  
 [Neutraface](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020145725/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=615) from House Industries  
 [Eagle](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020145725/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Eagle) from The Font Bureau  
 [Mostra](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020145725/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=mostra&x=0&y=0) from Mark Simonson Studio  
 [Bernhard Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020145725/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/urw/urw_bernhard_gothic/) from URW  
 [Agency](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020145725/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/AgencyFB) from The Font Bureau

I don't know about "great," but my own [Hypatia Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20131020145725/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/landing/hypatia/hypatia.html) would seem to fit the rest of that description. :)
:^/ I thought Hypatia was only available as an incentive. Sorry, T.
